sentences: Connie Smith (born Constance June Meador; August 14, 1941) is an American country music singer and songwriter.
Discovered in 1963, Smith signed with RCA Victor Records the following year and remained with the label until 1973.
Discovered in 1963, Smith signed with RCA Victor Records the following year and remained with the label until 1973.

Her debut single "Once a Day" was nominated at the Grammy Awards for Best Female Country Vocal Performance and reached number one on the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart in November 1964 and remained at the top position for eight weeks, the first time a female artist had achieved this feat, with Smith holding the record for over 50 years until it was broken by Trisha Yearwood.
She eventually went into semi-retirement in 1979.
However, it was not until her collaboration with Marty Stuart in the 1990s that she returned permanently.
Their musical friendship would turn romantic, leading to their marriage in 1997.
She has been a member of the Grand Ole Opry cast since 1965.
In 2012, Smith was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame.
Connie Smith was born Constance June Meador on August 14, 1941, to Wilma and Hobart Meador in Elkhart, Indiana.
In 1959, Smith graduated from Salem-Liberty High School as the class salutatorian.
In August 1963, she entered a talent contest at the Frontier Ranch country music park near Columbus, Ohio.
In January 1964, Smith ran into Anderson again at a country music package concert, where he invited her to perform with him on Ernest Tubb's Midnite Jamboree program in Nashville, Tennessee.
Also impressed by her vocals, Atkins offered Smith a recording contract, and she eventually signed with the label on June 24, 1964.
1964–1967: "Once a Day" and breakthrough =
Smith's first session took place on July 16, 1964, where she recorded four songs, three of which were written by Bill Anderson.
The song was rush-released as a single in August 1964 and reached number one on the Billboard Magazine Hot Country Singles chart on November 28.

RCA Victor released Smith's self-titled debut album in March 1965 which also reached number one spending seven weeks at the top of the Billboard Top Country Albums chart, and spending 30 weeks on the chart overall.
Her next Anderson-penned release was 1965's "Then and Only Then".
In 1965, Smith officially became a member of the Grand Ole Opry radio show in Nashville, Tennessee.
In the 1970s, Smith was nearly fired from the show for testifying about Jesus Christ.
Bill Anderson wrote her next single with Bette Anderson titled "I Can't Remember" (1965).
In October 1965, Smith released her second studio album Cute 'n' Country.

Her next two singles, "If I Talk to Him" and "Nobody But a Fool (Would Love You)", both reached number four on the country singles chart and were issued on Smith's third album, Miss Smith Goes to Nashville (1966).
This change of sound was evident on her next two studio albums: Born to Sing (1966) and Downtown Country (1967).
This change of sound was evident on her next two studio albums: Born to Sing (1966) and Downtown Country (1967).
In 1966, she appeared in the films Second Fiddle to a Steel Guitar and The Las Vegas Hillbillys, the latter of which starred Jayne Mansfield.
In 1967, she appeared in The Road to Nashville and Hell on Wheels.
In February 1967, Smith released an album on RCA Camden entitled Connie in the Country, which mainly featured cover versions of country hits recorded at the time.
In May 1967, RCA released an album of songs written entirely by Bill Anderson called Connie Smith Sings Bill Anderson.

Between 1966 and 1968, Smith had five top ten singles in a row on the Billboard country chart: "I'll Come Runnin'" (which Smith wrote herself), "Cincinnati, Ohio", "Burning a Hole in My Mind", "Baby's Back Again", and "Run Away Little Tears".
"Cincinnati, Ohio" would later inspire the city of Cincinnati, Ohio to declare their own "Connie Smith Day" in June 1967.
By 1968, Smith began to feel large amounts of pressure from the music business.
These pressures eventually led her to seek solace in both her family life and religion, becoming a Born Again Christian in the spring of 1968.
In 1968–69, she recorded a cover of Marty Robbins' "Ribbon of Darkness".
In 1969, her next single "You and Your Sweet Love" (written by Bill Anderson) reached number six on the Billboard Magazine Hot Country Singles chart.
This was followed by another top ten single in 1970 called "I Never Once Stopped Loving You", which reached the top five.
Between 1969 and 1970, she released two collaborative albums with Nat Stuckey: Young Love and Sunday Morning with Nat Stuckey and Connie Smith.
From 1970 to 1971, both the singles "Louisiana Man" and "Where Is My Castle" became top 20 hits on the Billboard country singles chart.
In 1971, Smith's cover of Don Gibson's "Just One Time" reached number two on the Hot Country Singles chart.
In 1971, she released her third gospel album, Come Along and Walk with Me.
In 1972, all three of Smith's singles reached the top ten on the country singles chart: "Just for What I Am", "If It Ain't Love (Let's Leave It Alone)", and "Love Is the Look You're Looking for".
In November 1972, Smith announced she would depart from RCA the same week that country artist Eddy Arnold also announced his temporary departure.
In 1973, Smith moved to Columbia Records.
Her first gospel record under the label was 1973's God Is Abundant.
She also recorded her first country LP for Columbia in 1973 titled A Lady Named Smith (produced by George Richey).
However Smith was dissatisfied with Richey's production strategies and replaced him with Ray Baker for her next album, That's the Way Love Goes (1974).
Her next single was written by Dallas Frazier called "Ain't Love a Good Thing", which peaked at number ten on the Hot Country Singles Chart in 1974.
In 1974, the singles "I Never Knew (What That Song Meant Before)" and "I've Got My Baby on My Mind", which both reached number 13 on the Billboard country chart.
In 1975, she released her second gospel album with the label, entitled Connie Smith Sings Hank Williams Gospel.
In 1976, Smith released two cover versions of previously made pop hits by The Everly Brothers as singles: "(Till) I Kissed You" and "So Sad (To Watch Good Love Go Bad)".
In 1977 Smith moved to Monument Records.

While reviewing Smith's 1993 Monument compilation Greatest Hits on Monument, Allmusic's Stephen Thomas Erlewine commented that she not only recorded country-pop material, but also "heavily produced adult contemporary ballads and big, shiny disco-influenced pop numbers."
Her debut 1977 Monument album, Pure Connie Smith, spawned the single "Coming Around", which peaked outside the country top 40.
Only one single released on the label became a significant hit, a cover of Andy Gibb's 1977 pop hit "I Just Want to Be Your Everything".
The track reached number 14 on the country singles chart in 1978.

Her next five singles on the label continued to descend into progressively lower positions on the country singles chart and because of poor record sales, Smith decided to go into semi-retirement in 1979 to raise her five children.

1964–1967: "Once a Day" and breakthrough =
One of the four songs recorded during the session entitled "Once a Day" was chosen to be Smith's debut single.
The song was rush-released as a single in August 1964 and reached number one on the Billboard Magazine Hot Country Singles chart on November 28.
It remained at the number one position for eight weeks.
"Once a Day" became the first debut single by a female country artist to reach number one.
For nearly 50 years the single held the record for the most weeks spent at number one on the Billboard country chart by a female artist.
